captions.text: Ponder this my friends:

If you were born inside of a box,
would the thought of the world outside it

- a world that is more real -
ever enter your mind?

Considered one of philosophy's
greatest writers, Plato asked

just this sort of question
in his famous allegory of the cave.

Imagine a group of people born into a cave,
chained by their legs and necks,
facing the back wall.

The only thing they can see 
are shadows cast by a fire behind them,

and since they've never seen the actual objects, 
they think the shadows are real.

But what would happen if one of
the prisoners were to be set free?

When he turns around and sees the objects, will he 
know that the shadows are a lesser copy of reality?

And when he eventually leaves the cave and 
sees the sun and nature for the first time,
would his mind not be completely blown?

But wait a sec. If the objects are more real
than the shadows, how do we know there isn't
something more real than the objects?

The ultimate reality is what Plato calls
the real of the forms.

It is eternal, unchangeable;
it is the realm of being, of what is.

Our world, on the other hand,
is the world of becoming,

of change and what we perceive, where everything 
is constantly becoming something else.

Just as the shadow of an object is
a faded copy of the actual object,

the world as we perceive it consists
of imperfect copies of the forms.

After experiencing a higher truth, what would 
happen if the prisoner returned to the cave?

Plato muses that telling the others of the greater 
reality would threaten their narrow beliefs.
If they could...
...they might even kill him.

Will we as humans ever be able to lose our 
shackles of perception, and truly know reality?

title: What is Real? (Plato's Allegory of the Cave) - 8-Bit Philosophy

comments.text:
the problem with this argument is the idea that shadows are less real than 
the objects that cast them. shadows are just as real as the physical 
objects that cast them, and shadows are a physical phenomenon. they didn't 
understand this in Plato's time. we do understand it know. our 
understanding of reality may be flawed but it is no indication of another 
reality or an ultimate reality. an other reality may exist we are unable to 
perceive but this analogy is flawed so you cannot make a cogent argument 
about the other reality based on it.﻿

comments.text:
Ahem: No we won't.

What if we could stop perceiving stuff and just know the stuff?  I argue 
that we can perceive everything on a practical sense but just don't 
understand it enough.  Those moblins saw everything they needed to know 
about the reality of their cave... they just didn't *understand* the 
concepts of light casting a shadow when blocked by an opaque object.

There even would've been physical clues as to the existence of something 
beyond the cave... like airflow and noises.  They just didn't understand 
enough to recognize that which they would've perceived.

Also: Plato is a hack fraud. :P﻿

http://thespiritscience.net/2014/05/21/witty-animation-artistically-explains-multidimentional-existence-in-under-3-mins/

WITTY ANIMATION ARTISTICALLY EXPLAINS MULTIDIMENTIONAL EXISTENCE IN UNDER 3 
MINS


Once upon a time a man named Plato created a philosophy which clearly 
dictates the limiting perspectives of the conditioned mind and how our 
perceptions are created and accepted. If you didn’t understand that 
philosophy before, let me show you this video! This will explain it in a 
way you’ve never seen before.



Plato’s allegory of the Cave is the story and metaphor for our awareness of 
the reality we live in and our prospective of it. Many find it accurate to 
portray the reality we have perceived is akin to just shadows dancing on a 
wall, and everything we have previously believed to be true is simply a 
fraction of the experience of what is really going on in the bigger picture 
of things. With reality shown to us this way we can begin to understand how 
there are larger forces of being at play that govern the phenomenon that 
take place in this realm as well, just like the shadows in the story. Once 
we see that reality however, when we try to enlighten others sometimes its 
not so easy to decondition others, as many of you have seen in your own 
lives.
Sound like the twilight zone?



﻿

comments.author: Fireboy991

comments.text:
Nonsense! The shadow is as real as the object casting it. The shadow is 
cast because the object absorbs and reflects incoming light; it is merely 
the absence of light in a certain spot. It's not a 'less real' version of 
the object. It's not a version of the object at all! The shadow gives you 
information about the geometry and sometimes optical properties and 
consistency of the object casting it. Intelligent beings in this cave would 
sooner or later would realize that in fact it is a shadow cast by some 
object and not an object in itself. After all, in this settings, they would 
have shadows of their own and understand more or less how they work.﻿

comments.author: DFME007

comments.text:
It's an allegory, not an analogy. As such, it can have some symbolic and 
artistic freedom to communicate the message or idea that tries to explain 
or communicate. An allegory not necessarily has to be "bullet proof", all 
critics pointing the "holes" don't "fully" apply because being "exact" or 
"precise" isn't the intended end. It's an abstract (figurative) discourse, 
not a concret (literal) one. Greetings.
comments.author: MauricioACB

comments.text:
That is only because we now know what a shadow is, what it does and what it 
is caused by.

In application to real life, we are severely lacking knowledge of the 
possibility of other universes, other dimensions, etc. Therefore we don't 
know if there is a more *real* reality beyond what we label this one to be.

This universe is necessarily real, but necessity doesn't mean that it is 
actually true.

comments.author: Prescott Dux

comments.text:
+Lukas G Indeed as you said, the point Plato was trying to make overall is 
that there are things we can never know for sure. 

A lot of people here are rambling about the science of shadows and what not 
and other unimportant details, but we need to remember and appreciate the 
point of the story.

Plato's Cave teaches to be humble. We can be still be critical and have 
opinions, but we should all remember in the forefront of our minds that we 
could all be wrong. 

So many stupid people out there delude themselves by justifying their 
stupid ideas or denying their sins or convincing themselves that they are 
authentic human beings despite the fact that they follow the herd. You can 
argue with them all day long and they just can't conceive the possibility, 
not even accept a 0.001% that they could themselves be "living in a cave." 

This is why philosophy was created by brilliant men like Plato, in order to 
open the minds of men like these. This makes the world a much better place. 

Unfortunately, philosophical ideas are usually complicated, and even 
geniuses like Plato, despite their best efforts, have trouble simplifying 
their admirable ideas to the extent the majority of the world's idiots can 
understand them. Luckily there are people out there like you and I to 
spread the word, and even better, brilliant educators like 8-bit philosophy 
and wisecrack.
comments.author: LordWellington35

comments.text:
+LordWellington35
I don't know of any beeing not deluded by religion who thinks we can 
perceive the whole of existence. In science we constantly discover new 
things and found out that the universe works nothing like we conceive it 
with our natural senses but we are aware of our limited knowledge and that 
there are even more things we don't know and things we can never know 
(consider Gödel's incompleteness theorems or Heisenberg's uncertainty 
principle).

I find your attacks on arthurthegreat very immature and made with a narrow 
view, because it was also the first thing I as physics student was 
thinking: "Damn it! The shadow is as real as the object casting it!". I 
think the conclusion Plato draw as displayed in the video is very amazing 
considering his time. Today he would have formulated the shadow thing a 
little differently (or maybe the video just formulates it badly), but his 
point nevertheless is valid. It instantly reminded me of the science vs 
religion conflict happening today and in our recent past since the 
Enlightenment. Religion always tried to defend their narrow worldview with 
all means necessary especially as we started developing a tool now called 
the scientific method with which we could break the chains religion imposed 
on our thinking and started to see the world as it is, not as some 
authorities wanted us to see and think about it. But of course as I 
mentioned above, there are even more things we don't know and things we can 
never know.
comments.author: Lukas G

comments.text:
+arthurthegreat That's great and all, but I wasn't replying to you, unless 
you happen to own +spiritdragon as well.

I do agree that the video does not explain it well, but then again there 
are some significant time restraints for their videos. Plato's description 
is actually told as a story, and includes some caveats. The dwellers can 
not see each other or themselves, and are interacted with by people who use 
only puppets and items, they hide their actual shadows behind a wall. Plato 
used a great deal of thought and care in the preparation of the situation 
that is missing from the video. 

I would actually love to see the counterpoint arguments to some of the 
topics of these videos. For example the Knowledge Argument is very similar 
to Plato's Cave Allegory, and there has been a lot of debate on whether or 
not there are ways in which knowledge of something is sufficient to 
experience of something.

comments.author: arthurthegreat

comments.text:
+spiritdragon But it's not an analogy. That's the point some people have a 
hard time with. It's an allegory. Plato's allegory of the cave is a thought 
experiment that was never meant to be taken literally as an analogy. It 
does not 'assume' anything. In fact it does quite the contrary, as it is 
meant to cast doubt on the idea that one can fully know that the world 
around them is real.

I think what confuses people is thinking that the point is to show how the 
cave dwellers would have, as the video puts it, "their minds blown". But 
that's not really the crux of the idea. The true point is, as I understand 
it, that the cave dwellers lack the completeness of experience that those 
outside the cave have. Lacking the whole picture they can not imagine the 
'truth' of the world. Plato then points out that it is possible that we too 
lack the complete picture, and that reality as we know it is far greater 
then what we simply are capable of experiencing. 

I hope that explains it a bit better, but truly 'my' point is that it's not 
meant to be a factual account of actual cave dwellers in relation to the 
real world, but simply a conceptual idea to ponder about our own existence 
and understanding of reality.
comments.author: Shahared

comments.text:
I agree. It's a poor analogy to make since it is incorrect in its 
assumption.

comments.author: parasiticjustice

comments.text: +Julian Escobedo .... Shut up, Meg....
comments.author: LordWellington35

comments.text:
+LordWellington35
 Whether the prisoners do or do not cast a shadow is very important. Again, 
if they cast a shadow, sooner or later they'll experiment and realize to a 
certain degree what a shadow is, in which case the analogy won't hold. 
Incidentally, I think this thought experiment is even nicer because the 
stupid prisoner will keep thinking the shadow is an "object" in itself 
while the smart prisoner will use all available pieces of information (e.g 
his own shadow) in order to form a more accurate worldview. The smart 
prisoner would be analogous to scientists.

A sound thought experiment shouldn't have holes; you can't apply the laws 
of nature at your convenience (some objects cast shadow while others 
don't). I know I'm being a bit pedantic but a thought experiment that 
survived and been pondered by so many people should be bulletproof and this 
one definitely isn't. Of course I understood the point it was trying to 
convey, all I'm saying it conveys it shabbily... 

What if our existence is a part of a "higher plane" of existence? So what? 
There are infinite number of unfalsifiable what-if scenarios such as this. 
All we can do (like the smart prisoner mentioned above) is observe, reason 
about and experiment with nature in order to arrive at more accurate 
pictures of existence and learn how to better use it to our advantage. 
Going on metaphysical journeys that have no foundation in reality and 
explore the what-ifs may be a bit amusing but will never produce any useful 
conclusions.
comments.author: arthurthegreat

comments.text: You didn't have to bash in the first place...
comments.author: Julian Escobedo

comments.text:
For one, you're missing the entire point of the video. Secondly you are 
reading into his words too literally. 

Right off of the bat, notice how in the video it doesn't show the 
reflections of the prisoners? Even if it did, it wouldn't matter since I 
don't think a person in their circumstances we be able to reasonably 
conclude that the shadows are merely shadows as we know shadows to be. 
However this point is completely irrelevant to what Plato is saying so lets 
ignore it. Lets pretend that the fire and sword or above them, or set in 
some position that no shadow is cast of the prisoners, but a visible shadow 
of the sword is cast. Assuming that, we can get to the main point. Now this 
may confuse your feeble mind so try and pay attention.

The prisoners see the sword's shadow as a real object in itself. Having 
lived their life in a cave, they have no concept of what a shadow is and 
would not be able to reasonably expect that the sword's shadow is merely a 
reflection of the actual sword. 

Now, we, as the viewers on the outside, can recognize that the shadow is 
not an object in itself but merely an "imperfect copy" of a real thing. 
Likewise, we understand that the cave is not the whole world, or the "whole 
of entire existence" as the prisoners would likely perceive it. The 
prisoners are so sure of themselves that the cave they live in is the truth 
of the world. It would be easy for us to laugh at them, to think the 
prisoners naive and uninformed. 

However just as how the prisoners are certain of the world, yet incorrect, 
how do we know that the we are not incorrect in what we perceive to be the 
whole of existence? We can view that what the prisoners see as universe is 
merely a cave that is part of a much larger world. How do we know that our 
world itself isn't merely a "cave" that is part of an even larger world, or 
another plane of existence? 

Another plane of existence may not existence. But we don't know for sure, 
so for the sake of argument we assume there is a higher plane for now. So 
for the shadow. If we can't be certain that we aren't just as dumb as the 
prisoners, and we can't be certain that our world isn't also merely a 
smaller sub-world within a larger universe, how can we be sure that what we 
see as the sword, the "real object," isn't also a "shadow" that is being 
reflected from that larger world? 

I mean shadow in the metaphorical sense of course. What I mean is, how do 
we know that the sword we see isn't also an "imperfect copy", "flawed 
reflection", or distortion of an object resting that higher plane of 
existence? 

Short answer, we can't. It is impossible to know for sure.

comments.author: asil

comments.text:
+Robot HandLove I come to understand that you are a critic / believer, You 
only complain about your disliking towards the argument with no relevant 
point to mention. Criticism is a powerful too when accompanied by a better 
solution.

Let's take your onion analogy for example, where you a acknowledge the 
presence of the other layers but fail to have any motivation to explore it 
cause you assume boundaries with the hope of simplifying things by making a 
choice. Once you make a choice that the only layer in which you exist 
matters to you, finally resulting rejecting other scenarios just because 
they are irrelevant for you currently.

If all the human kind was just content with living in reality we would not 
have had telescopes/microscopes to understand the vastness of the universe 
or mysteries of the quantum realm.

Science is a mere tool to answer giving solutions and explanations, and 
philosophy has always been about asking questions, Questions that force you 
to think beyond the visible reality but still addressing our existence and 
relevance as life . .﻿
